question.text: A human body has a surface area of approximately <math><mn>1</mn><mi> </mi><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> . The normal body temperature is <math><mn>10</mn><mi> </mi><mi>K</mi></math> above the surrounding room temperature <math><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> . Take the room temperature to be <math><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mi> </mi><mi>K</mi></math> . For <math><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mi> </mi><mi>K</mi></math> , the value of <math><mi>σ</mi><msup><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>460</mn><mfrac><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> (where <math><mi>σ</mi></math> is the Stefan-Boltzmann constant). Which of the following options is/are correct?

options.text: If the surrounding temperature reduces by a small amount <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mo><</mo><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi></math> , then to maintain the same body temperature the same (living) human being needs to radiate <math><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">σ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi></math> more energy per unit time
Reducing the exposed surface area of the body (e.g. by curling up) allows humans to maintain the same body temperature while reducing the energy lost by radiation.
If the body temperature rises significantly then the peak in the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation emitted by the body would shift to longer wavelengths
The amount of energy radiated by the body in 1 second is close to <math><mn>60</mn><mi> </mi><mi>J</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>s</mi></math>

solution.text:
\(\begin{aligned}

& \text { Energy radiated }=\sigma A\left(T^4-T_0^4\right) \mathrm{t} \\

& =\sigma A\left[\left(\mathrm{~T}_0+10\right)^4-T_0^4\right] t \\

& =\sigma A T_0^4\left[\left(1+\frac{10}{T_0}\right)^4-1\right] t \\

& =\sigma A T_0^4\left[\frac{40}{T_0}\right] \times t=460 \times 1 \times \frac{40}{300} \times 1=61.33 J \\

& P=\frac{\text { Energy radiated }}{\text { time }}=\sigma A T^4-\sigma A T_0^4 \\

& \therefore\left|\frac{d p}{d T_0}\right|=\sigma A\left(4 T_0^3\right) \therefore|d p|=\sigma A\left(4 T_0^3\right) d T_0 \\

& \therefore|\Delta P|=4 \sigma A T_0^3

\end{aligned}\)

A, B are not correct options as human body is not a black body. Energy radiated \(\propto \mathrm{A}\) where \(\mathrm{A}\) is the surface area of the body. ' \(\mathrm{C}\) ' is the correct option
